title: Myriad
content:
**[Indices](http://web.archive.org/web/20141119054200/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Indices) : [Typefaces](http://web.archive.org/web/20141119054200/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Typefaces) : Myriad**

A [humanist](http://web.archive.org/web/20141119054200/http:/typophile.com/wiki/humanist) [sans serif](http://web.archive.org/web/20141119054200/http:/typophile.com/wiki/sans%20serif) design that was the product of the collaboration between [Robert Slimbach](http://web.archive.org/web/20141119054200/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Robert%20Slimbach) and [Carol Twombly](http://web.archive.org/web/20141119054200/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Carol%20Twombly)with [Fred Brady](http://web.archive.org/web/20141119054200/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Fred%20Brady) & [Christopher Slye](http://web.archive.org/web/20141119054200/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Christopher%20Slye). Myriad was orignally released in [1992](http://web.archive.org/web/20141119054200/http:/typophile.com/wiki/1992).  
A prominent use of this typeface is by [Apple](http://web.archive.org/web/20141119054200/http:/typophile.com/wiki/www.apple.com) (it is actually Myriad Pro Semibold).

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20141119054200im_/http:/typophile.com/files/myrdpdh100806_4781.gif)
  
A comparison of the principal differing characters in Myriad and Frutiger\*.  
\* This is actually Bitstream's Humanist 777, which is based directly on the Frutiger typeface.
